content:
Posted: January 3, 2016
												Do you like Tower Defense?Do you like TPS?Do you like to smile and laugh at funny comments?Yes? Then there's no doubt that you should play this game!First things first: In case you wonder "Do I really need to play the original OMD! before playing this sequal?"Well, you don't need to, but if you would like the story to make sense to you, then yes. And really, the first game was excellent - and they simply improved the story by making OMD!2. So, I will only recommend buying (and playing) the first game and then continue with this one. I have spent hours playing both games in all modes - all for a great amount of fun!Certainly, some levels might be best in co-op mode (if not all of them) but you can have a splendid time taking on the game just by yourself, in case you were wondering.This is the best TD game I've played (others including Dungeon Defenders and Sanctum), simply because it adds humor, and have very challenging maps. I do HIGHLY recommend this game for anyone wanting to either challenge oneself; build up a better teamwork with a friend; or simply have lots of fun listening to the comments the War mage and Sorceress throw at each other.

content:
Posted: November 22, 2012
												My favourite tower defense game, just edging ahead of Plants Vs Zombies. Action-packed, hilarious and deeply satisfying when you start pulping Orcs in finely-tuned traps; hugely challenging and panic-inducing on harder difficulties when trying to stop that last Kobold from escaping. DLC just adds more to an already fantastic little experience, but don't expect a huge progression from the original Orcs Must Die!, because this is essentially just more- more traps, more maps, more characters (the Sorceress and a co-op mode). If that puts you off splashing out for it at full price, wait til it's on sale, because it's still eminently buyable and very, very enjoyable.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2013
												Quite fun actually. Orcs Must Die! 2 did not have a "wow-factor" for me in terms of the gameplay. I have played too much Dungeon Defenders to be new to third-person tower defense. What this game does shine in is the variety of traps, I enjoy having different load outs depending on the map and my play style. The pathing of waves are designed to be optimized for certain traps (ceiling, floor or walls). The game also supplies players with a good collection of weapons used on Orcs to company the automatic traps. In the game, there are only two classes to choose from; War Mage and Sorceress. The War Mage is a male character whose quotes are quite lighthearted but unintelligent. He has two "uniques" a trusty Blunderbuss, a shot-gun that also doubles as a grenade launcher, and Tar Trap that slows down enemies. The Sorceress, on the other hand, has a very different style. She is more of a passive character than the War Mage. Her unique trap, Acid Sprayer is able to apply short-term effects on enemies and her Sceptre of Domination can temporarily mind control. Even with the lack of characters, Orcs Must Die! 2 is still very enjoyable to play and, if single player is getting repetitive, online co-op is always available.

content:
Posted: September 4, 2014
												Orcs Must Die! 2You know one of these games in which you ask  yourself, "What were the developers thinking"?This is one of this, and this game has a really basic concept, but, after all, it's a really fun an entertaining game.All you need is a friend to play with, and clicking few buttons.The game's concept goes like this;You and your partner are meant to set up an ambush, and traps, to keep an X amount of Orcs getting through the Rift. The rift is shown up as a door with a dim yellow light coming from it, like something god-like. It's a defense game with waves; you can upgrade traps, outfits, gear, trinkets, and many more. Depending on what level you're on, the amount of waves and the enemy types may vary alot, and you'll have to figure out which is the best way to keep them from going through your 'fortress' in time.The game revolves around the basic and generic-kill everything theme, warriors and orcs. I don't have many hours in it, but even if you're a fan of extremely realistic, indie, or 2d games, no matter what, this game is pretty decent. At first you'll think it's plain simple and boring, but after you played it for a bit you'll get used to it, and the fun will start showing up. Play it with a friend, make up a plan, tactics, strategy, and then prove who's the king, the orcs, or your "devilishly handsome" protagonist, ha-ha.Good luck!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 10, 2013
												Quite fun actually. Orcs Must Die! 2 did not have a "wow-factor" for me in terms of the gameplay. I have played too much Dungeon Defenders to be new to third-person tower defense. What this game does shine in is the variety of traps, I enjoy having different load outs depending on the map and my play style. The pathing of waves are designed to be optimized for certain traps (ceiling, floor or walls). The game also supplies players with a good collection of weapons used on Orcs to company the automatic traps. In the game, there are only two classes to choose from; War Mage and Sorceress. The War Mage is a male character whose quotes are quite lighthearted but unintelligent. He has two "uniques" a trusty Blunderbuss, a shot-gun that also doubles as a grenade launcher, and Tar Trap that slows down enemies. The Sorceress, on the other hand, has a very different style. She is more of a passive character than the War Mage. Her unique trap, Acid Sprayer is able to apply short-term effects on enemies and her Sceptre of Domination can temporarily mind control. Even with the lack of characters, Orcs Must Die! 2 is still very enjoyable to play and, if single player is getting repetitive, online co-op is always available.

content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
												Do you like killing orcs? if so this is the game for you!!!No But Really Time For The Proper Review===============================Now what is orcs must die? It is a tower defence meets fps, at its core you are always trying to make brillent setups of many diffrent traps, some of them ar locked till you reach a certain ponit in the main story and allow you to buy them later on.Wait did I hear buy? Yep, as you play the game and unlock the right to buy certain traps. You earn skulls, these can be used to buy new traps, weapons and upgrade ones you already have. You can also buy some awesome skins.That is pretty much most of the game howeever, the game dose a great job by chllangeing you. The story steadly introduces new mobs and levels in a proper diffculty climb. You should never feel like a map is hopeless if you know what you are doing.Now another game mode is the games endless misssion. Wait wut endless missions so they go on forever? Yup, like the name entails I have been to some pretty high waves. and its really very fun.Still not convinced, well this game also suports mods adding great reply ablitty. However it is already very high due to its awesome endless mission, story and the veries diffcultiys it can be beat on and even offers to diffrent characters to play as.All in all this game has lots of content, always manages to pull me back in for a few waves amd still play it to this day with my friend after owning it for almost a year. You can not go wroung with this game. 8/10 would play again. In the words of Doge very fun, much hours.

content:
Posted: October 11, 2013
												Orcs Must Die! 2 (or "Orcs 2"/"OMD2") is an odd amalgamation of third-person action and tower defense.  This creates a very fun and interesting mixture of gameplay that can be balanced at the player's discretion.  The basic format of the game is this:You have a portal or sometimes multiple portals which must be protected from waves of enemies of increasing difficulty.  The portal has a set number assigned to it that goes down if you die or enemies enter it.  If and when that number reaches zero, it's GAME OVER!At the very start, you choose between two characters, who each have access to certain weapons and traps and shout of their own cheeky one-liners:Warmage - A very balanced character with about the same amount of health and mana.  Definitely made for those who prefer to get up close and personal with their enemies.Sorceress - A character designed for those who'd rather set up traps and guardians and snipe at enemies with ranged attacks.  The Sorceress has almost double the mana as the warmage, but at the cost of having almost half the health. Once you pick a character, it's time to choose your loadout of items and tools to protect your portal:- Traps - Good old-fashioned traps act like towers in any other tower defense game.  Most activate by themselves and have a recharge.  Some are a little different, but most fit this description.  There is a wide variety of traps to choose from with countless different effects.- Guardians - Guardians are living beings which you summon to help protect the portal.  They are very much like traps in that they automatically attack enemies, but they are different in that they can move around, do not have a recharge timer, and can die.  They can, however, be revived.- Weapons - These are what throw the third-person action elements into the mix.  Weapons, while not quite as plentiful as traps, do have a wide variety.  Each weapon has a primary attack which costs nothing and can be used over and over, as well as a secondary attack which uses up mana.  Those who have played the Elder Scrolls should be familiar with how mana (magicka or stamina) works.- Trinkets - These are similar to weapons in that you carry them on your person, but they are different in that they play a more supportive role than an offensive one.You must use a balance of these four tools to defend your portal against seemingly-endless hordes of trolls, gnolls, ogres, and - of course - orcs!  The variety of enemies is just as vast as the variety of counters you have waiting for them.Inside of each level you collect gold to buy traps and guardians.  You gain the gold by killing enemies and collecting coins that are dropped by certain enemies for bonus gold.  At the end of each level, you are awarded with orc skulls depending on how well you did.  You use these skulls to unlock and upgrade new weapons, traps, guardians, and trinkets.  You can also buy a few (and I mean only a FEW) outfits for your character to wear as well.The game modes themselves are not all that diverse, but they get the job done.  You have your basic campaign made up of about 30 levels (give or take) with a pretty mediocre storyline.  Then there's the "Endless" mode which is not really endless as it has only 50 waves, but it sure seems endless as you find yourself constantly in a race to keep up with the increasingly difficult enemies.  You can also try out several DLC maps as well as the weekly challenge map, which has you play as a specific character with a pre-defined loadout on a certain map to see how long you can last.All-in-all, this is a great game for the price and can be very addicting.  The challenge is through the roof at times and you must be prepared to lose, if only to learn your mistakes and try again.  This game is fantastic in singleplayer, but it's an absolute blast in co-op.  What's better than singlehandedly taking on the beastly orc hordes?  Why, taking on the beastly orc hordes with a buddy, of course!  If you're a fan of mixing tower defense and third-person action, then get this game!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
												Oh man, I got this on impulse on sale. I gave it a whirl and... became addicted. Why? Well, throwing Orks all over the place is kind of fun, but besides, it's all about doing better and finding ever more fiendishly clever ways of killing them pesky Orks and Ogers. And Goblins. There's a million and one ways of doing the deed in question. Now, this isn't a great review, I know, but I've gotten most of my online contacts to get it. They also liked it alot. Then I discovered coop. It's not a hard-core game, that's sure, but that's the point of a game, it's FUN, it's like playing Super Mario Bros for the first time, it's simple, it's straight forward, it's got no plot twists and it's got no gimicks. It's just pure straight foward fun. Also, the voice acting, although not extensive, makes for some funny moments. Try it, it's probably not everyone's cup of tea, but if you're looking for a game that you can pick up, play for an hour or so and then do something else and not regret wasting your time, then I would wager that this is the game for you.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Orcs Must Die 2 is a brilliant successor to the first. There are so many new levels, traps, trinkets, and a new character in addition to the levels from the first game added on. All of that plus the DLC for an extremely low cost makes this game worth the $10 you will spend on a Steam sale. Infact, I bought this game full price and I have no regret.The newly added cooperative play makes the playability of this game extremely high. There is always something to achieve whether that be the actual achievements or simply personal targets in-game. The time it takes to 5-skull every level on story mode and endless mode is long so there is no shortage of game content.Many reviews I see on here under the "only negative" category are complaints about issues I have not seen. Once you get a friend to play with, this game is endlessly fun.The only issue I have ever had with this game is a single broken achievement.10/10. Will definitely buy the next iteration.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												  Orcs Must Die! 2 at first glance seems like a classical tower defense. You lay traps and have to survive waves of monsters in increasing strength and size. So what makes this game better than other tower defense you may ask.   Firstly, the seamless graphics along with the interesting ability of playing an active and very important role in the defense is major to its sucess. You play as your character and you have to personally mow down the monsters where your traps fail.         Secondly, the monsters require different ways to kill them, a koboldd sprinter is a small and fast unit with not a lot of hitpoints that can bypass most basic traps quite quickly and so need to be coupled either with some well placed shots to the head or another trap to slow the kobold to stop it from passing, whereas a heavy orc warrior would simply require a lot of traps or armor-piercing traps or shots to kill it. This necessity to vary trap combinations and styles plays a major role to the enjoyability of the game.   Thirdly, there are a plethora of traps and weapons to choose from, each providing a unique play style and experience. Thus you can customise your character either too a mean, lean killing machine or you can upgrade your traps say and lay down so nasty little traps in choke points that obliterate the enemy.   Fourthly, the game is not easy. For people who are not very good at tower defense games playing on anything but apprentice level can be a challenge, this skill level requirement or at least a certain level of understanding of the game is necessary as the game is challenging and keeps you on your toes, especially at later stages in the story or in nightmare or endless mode.   Lastly, the aspect of the game that makes it stand out so much from other games is the great co-op aspect. Can you name another tower defense that looks good, plays great, constantly challenges you to play at your best and allows for so many customizations? I think not. So, unless you have found a better tower defense game I highly recommend this game to whoever is looking for a challenging fun and funny game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2013
												Orcs Must Die 2 continues right where 1 left off. The much-awaited multiplayer experience is here, but this review will be from a single-player standpoint.To start with, you get to pick between the Warmage and the Sorceress. Both have their strengths and weaknesses, but the Warmage simply feels easier to play with due to his superior health, superior tar trap, and arguably superior weapon. The Sorceress is better for charming single, large targets though, and her acid trap does more damage than the Warmage's Arrow Trap.Gameplay is more or less the same. If you played OMD1, this will all be familiar. The Elementalist girls are gone, which is a shame. This change means that you have less options to adjust to your enemies in the middle of a level. Fortunately any upgrades you purchased prior to battle can be reset at no cost. Autoballistae are now considered guardians, which means you can no longer spam them. I was sad about that as well.Amazingly they made the Gnolls more irritating. They seem to have more HP, run faster (both probably untrue, but it feels like it), and can now slow you upon hitting you, making escape impossible. A whole pack of them, especially in Endless mode (see below), will ruin your day.I'm rather disappointed that the campaign is so short. The first game took maybe 15-20 hours to complete, and had a good progression. OMD2 instead took me a mere 10 hours on normal difficulty. Granted, I already knew the basics of the game, but this was far shorter than I expected. DLC's extend the game's length a bit, but they contain no story segments, and thus you are basically playing for skulls (the game's peristent currency) and variety. Note that you'll have to play through Campaign again with another character if you want stuff unlocked on both characters.Endless mode is interesting. Waves come indefinitely and keep getting tougher until you can no longer handle it, much like Survival mode in other types of games. This mode by far is the biggest time-sink, though you are rewarded with plenty of skulls to compensate.If you like the first game and want a way to play it with friends, then OMD2 is the way to go. Overall it's an acceptable game. I still recommend the first game though.

content:
Posted: April 18, 2014
												Orcs Must Die 2 is the sequel to Orcs Must Die (obviously) and as lazy as it sounds I would recommend reading my review of that because this game is essentially the same again. Not that that's a bad thing! The formula works, hell in this one they even improved a few things.This time you can choose between 2 characters to play as, the apprentice or the antagonist from the previous game. Each of the characters has their strengths and weaknesses, the apprentice carries on as he did before but now gives you the choice of crossbow, blunderbuss. The crossbow being the same as the last game and the blunderbuss causing far more damage but having a much longer reload time. The sorceress has less health than the apprentice but more mana and she can control a Orc and make him fight the others for a short period. As well as that some of the starting traps are different depending on which you choose as well as a few unlockables later.Speaking of traps there are some new ones, all of which are entertaining to see unfold, the levels also sometimes have environmental traps built in which you can take advantage of.This time there are far more unlockables to collect, costumes that change your abilities, rings and trinkets to enhance the way you play and of course the upgrades.Like the first game it's repetitive as hell, but what do you expect? And also like the first it's difficulty seems to ramp up out of nowhere.I recommend this game to those who have either played the first and want more of the same. If your new to the series... Well start here. It's a better game really, since it's the first one plus extras.I'd say £11.99 is a little steep though considering the first is essentially the same minus a few parts. See if you can find it a bit cheaper or on a sale. Anything below £10 is a bargain really.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 16, 2013
												It's the sequel to Orcs Must Die! Here comes more orc-slaughtering mayhem at its absolute finest! This iteration has better graphics, more refined & compelling strategy, genuinely creative & exciting maps, and waaaay more delicious, delicious unlockables than the original (the hunger for skulls will be extreme - you've been warned!). There are several DLC packs now available which do an admirable job of forcing you to develop new killing techniques and motivating you to persist in slicing & dicing orcs (along with the newly added enemies) in order to earn yet more skulls which (as in the first game) are the currency with which you purchase new items and upgrades.The crown jewel of this genocidal romp... The area where it *really* shines is, without a doubt, the co-op multi-player. This game has provided me with the most fun I've ever had with other players here on Steam. Grab this game (and all the DLC!) for yourself and a good friend, hop onto a Ventrilo or Teamspeak server and you absolutely won't regret the gore-soaked results. Best played with a 360 controller (in my opinion anyway; though a certain Aussie friend of mine insists that mouse/keyboard control is the way to go) and an unquenchable thirst for chaos on an orc-pocalyptic scale. Yeah, I said it. I went there. I regret nothing!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Super fun and addictive Third person tower defense game, made even better with the co-operative aspect of the game.Both characters play differently with different starting weapons and a couple unique traps....and of course there is loads to do from the range of main game levels (about 20), DLC levels (should you choose to buy them; 3 levels each), endless mode (a few) and classic levels (if you have the first game purchased; 10 levels)Pros:+Super fun and well-polished gameplay/animations.+Massive range of traps, trinkets, weapons etc. ALL with upgrades.+Great range of maps, some easy and some painfully hard.+Improves on the first game majorly, great sequel!+Solo and co-op options (can do a playthrough with a mixture).+Fantastic soundtrack.+Nightmare Mode for when the first playthrough was too easy.+Spring traps...seriously, they fling enemies all around the place.+Leaderboards for when you want to show up your friends.+When an orc cries out for it's mommy whilest getting sucked into a grinder (does this make me a bad person?).Cons:-The weekly challenges are often either stupidly hard or impossible by yourself, and i've 5-skulled everything.-"Crunch" (Level) - Maybe this level was a bit too hard to 5 skull on nightmare mode (especially solo).-The 'pros' list is too long.Seriously, even if you don't have a friend to play it with, it's still awesome; get it.Just watching hoards of orcs mindlessly run into your chaotic and unavoidable traps would make anyone's day.

content:

												This has to be one of the best Tower Defense games I've ever bought & played! The only problem is that theres is a lot of orcs - orcs that MUST die! 10/108/8/15 UpdateHere's a more descriptive view on the game, but a short one. Orcs Must Die! 2 is a sequel to the original, bringing us more gorey ways in destroying the one-sided army of the bloodthirsted Orcs. In protecting each given stronghold, given many traps and trinkets to fend them off in any given way possible to your imagination. All the while, progressing through the story of fending off the last strongholds against the growing threat.Anyways, I loved the game from the start, being able to choose different routes and ways to take each level, all the while, being competitive to take the first place within your Friend Leaderboard to show you were the best one to make a route crazy enough to be that well, in the first place. While with DLC to offer you more ways to slay them all down, there isn't a way to truly put a stop the Orc's, as they just keep coming, until their prepared army is scaled down to nothing but dust. Strategies has and always will be present, in progressing through the game itself.

A Screenshot of Orcs Must Die! 2
By: AguilaDeAcero




Well.. you know...( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)Ha! But for real now. The game it's a solid "Tower" Defense game (with a nice twist), a third person action game and also has nice rpg elements in it (like unlocking new traps, weapons, upgrades and so on). Also the sense of humour it's a nice touch and well done overall, I just wish there were more lines or voice acting between the 2 main characters. Yeah I know, you are here for the killing but the interaction and presentation of the game really got me hooked and wanted to know even more about the story and characters.The game has coop, and some modes to keep things fresh but I'm having a blast with endless mode for the moment. Oh, and the game has steamworkshop built in so that's a nice plus too. I only wish there were more sorceress skins over there.. yeah.. Very good game and addictive too. Give it a try.

content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												At the time of this posting, Orcs Must Die 2 is 90% off; That's less than $2!Orcs Must Die 2 is a tower defence game that puts equal emphasis on the player and the traps he/she places, as in one cannot win without the other on the harder difficulties. You can choose the 4-8 traps, weapons, and utilities you use at the beginning of each round, and upgrade them too. The upgrade system allows you to choose one of two unique stat buffs / extra abilities, and gives an additional aspect to modify your items each round. There is a lot of clicking involved for some personal items (especially the sorceress's Staff of Domination). Co-op is also an aspect which, in my opinion, enhances the experience to a degree; However, the game can be completed entirely alone.The OST is most noticable during the beginning of the waves, and the last wave, where it conveys the chaos taking place when the late-game waves start throwing hundreds of orcs, imps, golems and trolls at you. Orcs Must Die 2 definately has some charm to it's presentation.Overall, I think it's a no brainer to pick it up on sale, as it provided me with a good 20 or so hours of fun (though I did not complete all DLC maps)

content:
Posted: August 5, 2012
												Fans of the original game will find OMD2 mostly enjoyable. The gameplay mechanics are identical, but there are lots of new traps, weapons and avatar buffs, all of which have several upgrades to select. There are also a couple of new orc types. The result is even more tactical depth and playing style diversity. Story mode seems a bit short compared to OMD1, but replayability is extended by the game type called Endless, where the objective is to survive as many waves as possible before you get overrun. And then there's coop mode, but this isn't necessarily a good thing. Some of the maps seem to be specifically designed for two players, with far too many orcs coming from too many directions for one player to cover all at once. This makes some maps frustrating to play, even after hours of grinding Endless for enough skulls to fully upgrade your traps. I don't mind difficult games, but OMD2 at times simply feels unfair to solo players. Overall though OMD2 is still worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Third Person Shooter meets unusually placed tower defence. I was actually surprised when I realized how well they work together.  The Orcs Must Die! was really good, and got me hooked for a while (never could beat the last level :( ), but once I beat it I never really saw much to go back for. The second, however, adds co-op to the mix, and trust me when I say that the co-op is almost required. Trying to do the game solo is near impossible. But with the help of a friend, you can both have a blast (at the orcs) while you laugh away. A real friend builder, that's what this game is. If your friend is one that doesn't take things very serious, this game will prove that he/she is not good at doing anything where his/her actions help/hurt. If you have a perfect fit of a friend, where you work together like a well-oiled machine, your friendship will fly to the next level. Get the game, and get a friend a copy of the game. You can see if you are good friends right in here.

												Gotta hankering for mass murdering orc's while they charge linear paths and try to kill you and your nexus? lol Well buy this game. Its kinda one of those games you can just pick up and put down and always come back. The leaderboards are a nice addition if you're feeling competitive with friends or online players. I recommend playing with a friend tho lol. Just makes it much more fun and better time investment.core game play is simple. Kill X waves of enemies get gold spend on a Large verity of traps to stop the enemy dead in their tracks!  You'll find out soon that each new level gets a bit more difficult and always has a twist. Either new paths for the enemy or a new type. Flying , Elemental , Troll, or special unit with unique aspect.The starting levels are pretty simple but later planning and resource management will be a thing. But its always fun to retry for that perfect score. :)Buy it and have a good time with a friend totally worth it. :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
												My only complaint about this awesome sequel is that the main campaign is blatantly unfinished, lasting only 15 levels over the previous game’s 24, and going out on somewhat of a whimper. Act 3 is completely missing, and most of the new monsters only appear in the skimpy DLC with 3 levels each, no voice acting and no story included. But instead of an Act 3, we got a new playable character with a different tech tree, ONLINE CO-OP, a staggeringly large armory of weapons, an endless mode with over a dozen maps, a new dwarven mines setting with awesome environmental hazards which half the game takes place in, a unique challenge level that cycles every week, about a dozen maps from the first game (if you own it on Steam), 3 DLC packs with freaky new monsters and good weapons, and Steam Workshop integration so you can play with mods you like. Also included are many very welcome interface changes, such as not having to pick your weapons again every time you restart a level, and a set-up break before Nightmare levels. A very fun, very worthy sequel that expands and improves upon the original. Have fun earning thousands of skulls to purchase all the upgrades… and then do it all over again with the other character! It’ll keep you busy for a long time. But enjoy it while it lasts, because OMD3 is a free-to-play League of Legends clone. (Ugh… why??!!)

content:
Posted: March 14, 2016
												I got this game on a good sale with most of the dlc included, so here's my review.Great game, lots of fun with a friend.I gotta be honest I had bought Orcs Must Die (the first game) and I just could never get into the game, but this game has improved in alot of ways and the online CO-OP brings it to a whole new lvl- highly recommended ;) !Basically the idea of this game is simple, but the execution is not ;) .The goal of the game is to stop the baddies (mostly orcs, thus the game's name) from reaching the ending points once they spawn at starting points.Easy enough right?  Wrong =p plenty of enemy types, and lot and lots of them.  And how you go about attacking them is totally up to you and the tools you choose to get the job done.There are various different traps, helpers (guardians), trinkets (like armor pieces), and weapons you can equip and upgrade via skulls you earn from how you do on each lvl you play through, fun process and makes it have something to work towards ;) ; rewarding to say the least.Even at full price I'd can whole heartedly recommend this game, the dlc on other hand I'm not totally sure of yet, b/c most of the dlc was included in the pack I bought, so hard for me to judge the bang for buck on the dlc.Fun game though.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												Gotta hankering for mass murdering orc's while they charge linear paths and try to kill you and your nexus? lol Well buy this game. Its kinda one of those games you can just pick up and put down and always come back. The leaderboards are a nice addition if you're feeling competitive with friends or online players. I recommend playing with a friend tho lol. Just makes it much more fun and better time investment.core game play is simple. Kill X waves of enemies get gold spend on a Large verity of traps to stop the enemy dead in their tracks!  You'll find out soon that each new level gets a bit more difficult and always has a twist. Either new paths for the enemy or a new type. Flying , Elemental , Troll, or special unit with unique aspect.The starting levels are pretty simple but later planning and resource management will be a thing. But its always fun to retry for that perfect score. :)Buy it and have a good time with a friend totally worth it. :)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
												Honestly, I was skeptical about this game, just watching people play on youtube. My friend kinda coaxed me into getting it, and it's probably the most amazing game I've played in a long time! The game is a bit short, but does provide lots of replay ability through the different modes OMD2 incorporates. This game can get a little monotonous at times, but when playing with a friend it can provide hours of entertainment. ~Pros~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~1.) Enemies are fun and make the game challenging at points; A fair amount of the enemies in this game are unique, and have different weaknesses, attacks and strategies. It makes for interesting gameplay!2.) Ragdolls are wonderful; When aren't orcs flying through the air into a wall funny?3.) Replayability is good; The game doesn't make you start over when finished, and gives the ability to reset the skulls you put into your traps and weapons, allowing you to try new things. OMD2 also gives a harder version of the campaign, and a mode called endless; which is basically just play until you lose. 4.) Great customization; I'm mainly talking about the traps here. Each trap has 2 different abilities to it, but you can only choose one. There are lots of different combos you can perform by tweaking at the abilities of your traps.5.) Differentiation between characters; The sorcerer and war mage are not entirely the same, and have different traps as well as weapons, allowing the player to choose their play style.~Cons~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~1.) Online seems barren; Ihaven't seen anyone online, so this game can get lonely without a friend.2.) Traps sell for the same as they were bought; I wouldn't really list this as a con, it's more in the middle of the both. When you buy a trap, at any point in the game you can sell it for the exact amount of money. With certain overpowered traps this can become slightly game breaking, and tends to remove the challenge in some occasions. However it's great in the fact that you can remove it and replace it somewhere else. I constantly misclick xD so for me this is great. 3.) Seems like an addition to the first game rather than a sequel; I think most people could agree, this game kinda seems like an adaptation of the first one.Overall, this is a fantastic game, I highly recommend it to anyone who hasn't bought it yet, and is thinking of doing so :)

content:
Posted: March 17, 2016
												Quick Summary: Orcs Must Die 2 is the co-op follow-up to the original game and while there are changes in maps and some of the traps, the core gameplay is the same. This is a good thing because the first Orcs Must Die is awesome, and only lacked the ability to play with your friends.Spoilers AheadIf you’ve played the first Orcs Must Die recently you will remember that at the end, the war mage (you) closed the rifts into the orc world and trapped the evil sorceress on the other side with her minions. Closing the rifts had the side effect of making magic unusable, so the power she had over the orcs is gone, and now they want her dead. In this sequel, one last rift is opened by an old wise wizard (presumed dead in the first game) and the sorceress has escaped being chased by her former orcs. It’s team up time, and the war mage must work with the sorceress to stop the hordes of orcs from breaking through the rift into the human world. This time around you can choose which character to play the game as: war mage or sorceress. Mostly they’re the same but each has a couple of traps unique to them.  For example the war mage has the tar trap (one of the best floor traps) and the sorceress has the acid spray wall trap (decent against heavy enemies). Consensus seems to be that war mage is better overall. I played the sorceress and had fun with the polymorph ring against the super heavy enemies.Just like the first Orcs Must Die, the game is broken up into a series of independent map levels, and every level you start from scratch setting up traps and barricades to kill all the orcs before they reach the rift (or rifts). It’s a hybrid tower defense/third person shooter, so you’re in the thick of the action, blasting enemies along with your traps, or mopping up the ones who manage to break past. Every level you beat gives you “skulls” which are currency to buy upgrades for traps or unlock new spells/traps. Unlike the first game, you can replay levels over and over to farm skulls and eventually buy every upgrade. Pros:+Co-op campaign! You can play every level with a friend. This along with the skull farming adds a lot of replayability to the campaign.+Pretty much everything good in the first game is still there, including maps for the first game. You can play the “classic levels” with the new traps and sorceress character.Cons:-The “endless mode” gets buggy as you get to higher levels. Maybe it’s my computer but it really started to lag around wave 35. It actually crashed for me a couple times.Overall, if you liked Orcs Must Die 1, you should like part 2. They’re basically the same game with added improvements, options, and levels for the sequel.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 23, 2016
												At the time of this posting, Orcs Must Die 2 is 90% off; That's less than $2!Orcs Must Die 2 is a tower defence game that puts equal emphasis on the player and the traps he/she places, as in one cannot win without the other on the harder difficulties. You can choose the 4-8 traps, weapons, and utilities you use at the beginning of each round, and upgrade them too. The upgrade system allows you to choose one of two unique stat buffs / extra abilities, and gives an additional aspect to modify your items each round. There is a lot of clicking involved for some personal items (especially the sorceress's Staff of Domination). Co-op is also an aspect which, in my opinion, enhances the experience to a degree; However, the game can be completed entirely alone.The OST is most noticable during the beginning of the waves, and the last wave, where it conveys the chaos taking place when the late-game waves start throwing hundreds of orcs, imps, golems and trolls at you. Orcs Must Die 2 definately has some charm to it's presentation.Overall, I think it's a no brainer to pick it up on sale, as it provided me with a good 20 or so hours of fun (though I did not complete all DLC maps)

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												 +) All personal and other upgrades have become masteries you can get before the game, as long as you have skulls for them. You don't have to choose one of them and dump the others like in the first series. +) Aiming got even better. +) Your choice of traps and items from spellbook are fixed on your hotkeys so you don't have to click 'B' and select them all over again in every new game like in the first series. +) Weapons, rings and such stay where you appointed them on the slot. They don't push them selves forward to 1 or 2 like in the first series. You put them at 9, they stay at 9. +) Graphics have become a little clearer: better. There was no problem in the graphics in previous series but it just got better and that's a good thing. -) The number of campaign missions have decreased. I would prefer the length of first series. -) In Campaign mode I keep hearing the beautiful sexy lady's voice but she's not actually in the game. It would've been amazing if she follows you around and fight with you as a NPC.

content:
Posted: February 24, 2016
												Got the complete package for 2.49 so of course this game was worth it. However, I probably would have not bought this at full price (25% reason being that I'm poor).The game itself is great. A tower defense+FPS with funny dialouge and great graphics. Very fun game. My only complaint about this is the mouse. The mouse sensitivity is quite high which can be annoying. It gets annoying trying to turn the other way and somehow the the screen makes a 360. With that being said, the aiming can get tough too, especially trying to shoot the fast runners. Swing your cursor to fast, you're gonna miss the target. Swing it slow, you're gonna miss the target. Other than that, great game, and very well worth the price on sale.

A Screenshot of Orcs Must Die! 2
By: AguilaDeAcero




Well.. you know...( ͡° ͜ʖ ͡°)Ha! But for real now. The game it's a solid "Tower" Defense game (with a nice twist), a third person action game and also has nice rpg elements in it (like unlocking new traps, weapons, upgrades and so on). Also the sense of humour it's a nice touch and well done overall, I just wish there were more lines or voice acting between the 2 main characters. Yeah I know, you are here for the killing but the interaction and presentation of the game really got me hooked and wanted to know even more about the story and characters.The game has coop, and some modes to keep things fresh but I'm having a blast with endless mode for the moment. Oh, and the game has steamworkshop built in so that's a nice plus too. I only wish there were more sorceress skins over there.. yeah.. Very good game and addictive too. Give it a try.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 5, 2012
												Fans of the original game will find OMD2 mostly enjoyable. The gameplay mechanics are identical, but there are lots of new traps, weapons and avatar buffs, all of which have several upgrades to select. There are also a couple of new orc types. The result is even more tactical depth and playing style diversity. Story mode seems a bit short compared to OMD1, but replayability is extended by the game type called Endless, where the objective is to survive as many waves as possible before you get overrun. And then there's coop mode, but this isn't necessarily a good thing. Some of the maps seem to be specifically designed for two players, with far too many orcs coming from too many directions for one player to cover all at once. This makes some maps frustrating to play, even after hours of grinding Endless for enough skulls to fully upgrade your traps. I don't mind difficult games, but OMD2 at times simply feels unfair to solo players. Overall though OMD2 is still worth playing.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 11, 2015
												If you like tower defense and coop play, then this is a bull's-eye. It's a well crafted tower defense with third person perspective rather than an RTS perspective. The graphics do their job well enough, and the aesthetics are great for my taste. It has some short cut scenes and a little story you can follow, but puts most of the focus on the actual gameplay. Fun, easy to grasp and quite a lot of customization with multiple choices of skills and traps as well as leveling these up.Play it with a friend, or even better, a loved one. Worth the full price, particularly if you like tower defense, coop games, or third person action games.

content:
Posted: February 17, 2014
												Third Person Shooter meets unusually placed tower defence. I was actually surprised when I realized how well they work together.  The Orcs Must Die! was really good, and got me hooked for a while (never could beat the last level :( ), but once I beat it I never really saw much to go back for. The second, however, adds co-op to the mix, and trust me when I say that the co-op is almost required. Trying to do the game solo is near impossible. But with the help of a friend, you can both have a blast (at the orcs) while you laugh away. A real friend builder, that's what this game is. If your friend is one that doesn't take things very serious, this game will prove that he/she is not good at doing anything where his/her actions help/hurt. If you have a perfect fit of a friend, where you work together like a well-oiled machine, your friendship will fly to the next level. Get the game, and get a friend a copy of the game. You can see if you are good friends right in here.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
												For sure a wonderful game! It brings a lot of fun to a concept I havent seen done this well in a long time. The game pits you against angry mobs of orcs and other mythical creatures and does it with simplicity and fun!The game starts with a short story about why the orcs are attacking and so on and so forth. However from there you start. Orcs spawn from a single (or up to 4 locations later on) location and have one goal. Reach a predetermined  "door" if you will on the map, and beat the heck out of anything that stands between them and the objective. If too many enemies pass through the door you must retry the level.You can choose between two characters. A male character or a female character. The male character comes equipped with a shot gun and his own set of default traps to throw off enemies with. The female caracter comes with a wand that you can shoot either lower power bolts from faster or shoot charged up high damage bolts that also have a short ranged knockdown effect on enemies around the enemy hit with it. The game offers new traps,trinkets, and weapons avalible to your character iin the spellbook. The in game store that uses skulls as currency that you obtain through beating levels. Everything is upgradable and it's always fun to see what kind of damage you can do with an uprgraded trap or weapon.Co-op is the name of the game for the best fun in this game. Grab a buddy and you two can stop the orcs together! It's the same concept as playing alone except for that you get to do it with a friend. For me it return my mind to a simpler time sitting in my parents living room ripping through a game with a freind. It's great fun!The game also comes with an endless mode in which enemies spawn in an infinite number of waves. It adds a lot of replay value after a somewhat short campaign. (maybe 5 to 6 hours).Put aside anydoubt and pick up this game if you think it looks good. It's a great buy and will give you lots of entertainment especially with the three DLC pack bringing new levels and weapons. An easy 9/10 for me!

This game becomes tougher as you play but also more rewarding, if you are having trouble with a stage, why not have a buddy help you out. Over all its a fun addicting experience.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2013
Best tower defense game I've played in my life!This game is one of my favorite games, and I still play it very often even now, though I'll try not to be biased.One thing I'd like to point out is this was sort of made for co-op, though singleplayer is managable.If you want the game made for 1 person OMD1 although more dated has easier levels.The good things about this game Weapons - All the weapons are useful in some way, my most used ones are probably the lightning ring, ice amulet and bladestaff (freezing them and hitting them with the bladestaff's a really good combo)- Unique weapons to your character - The sorceress gets access to the polymorph ring, and a staff with the ability to temporarily charm orcs, if they die during the charm they stun and damage nearby enemies. Warmage gets the blunderbuss, king in direct damage, and the warhammer, able to clear entire areas in seconds.- Stuns. Without stunning certian enemies you'd probably die too fast, especially as the glass cannon, the sorcererTraps- Although some players are more comfortable with sticking to certain traps, switching what you use based on maps can help.- Most traps can combo, such as tar with arrow walls to trap people and damage them a ton- Lots of traps to knock enemies off the map! Watching them fly is funny.The bad things- Endless mode gets "harder" by giving higher health enemies after around wave 40 ish- Certian traps seem useless, such as the one-time use "Boom Barrel" Though I'd say around 90% of the traps are useful on certian maps or situations.- Tar is overpowered (900 gold to slow the entire lane by a ton? Yes please.)- Some weapons I think shouldn't be part of the DLC mostly just the gaurdian trinket (resurect dead gaurdians, passive heal)These are all the negatives I can think of.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2016
												When people talk about the traps being nerfed they weren't kidding. Every single second you have to micro manage each pathway and it gets extremely stressful. I was a fan of the orginal because it was better balanced, traps could actually kill, and you were rewarded with headshots.And to top it all off it has a saving problem, I played on endless mode today for about two hours straight. I quit the game like normal and all of the items that I unlocked were now locked again. Sad part about this is that I was actually going to give this game a positive score despite all it's flaws, don't get me wrong it can still be fun but the saving system made me lose my marbles with this game. Video games are already a waste of time to begin with, but never allowing me to advance even makes me feel even worse.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 17, 2013
												This is a third-person tower defense game...i guess that's what you can call it :)You have to defeat orcs before they reach a portal (or multiple portals).In order to stop them, you can place different traps throughout the level, but you can also shoot them yourself, which is definitely harder and not as fast, so using traps is needed in order to stop them.You can upgrade your weapons and traps by earning skulls, which you will get after completing a level or when they drop randomly while killing orcs.You have mutliple types of orcs like flying ones, fast ones, strong ones etc. which need different tactics or traps to defeat them fast enough.It is a lot of fun, especially in co-op. So grab it if you like those kind of games.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2014
												FUN Trap Defense!  Gibs & flyin' ragdolls galore.  The comedy actually makes me laugh, as it's quite dark, yet with that TF2 sort of physics feel that makes for 3 Stooges escapades when traps are launched..  There is always another reason to play a level another way for strategy, score, or just plain silliness.  Although a few of the levels feel a bit cramped or limited, by changing traps or weaponry one can overcome and appreciate the puzzler aspect of the game, hidden beaneath all the gore & violence.  "Orcs Must Die 2" is a really good time.

content:
Posted: April 17, 2013
												This game is very...unexpectedly engrossing. The developer team made many efforts for the combination of stuffs. At first, it has the most amount of stuffs(including weapons, trinkets and guardians) so far during the tower defense genre. Secondly, the combination of different traps, weapons and trinkets makes its strategies much more extensive and variable. All right, I admit its normal mode is quite a bit easy. But in nightmare and endless mode,you will pay more concentration on the combination of different useful stuffs for victory. Its co-op mode is another excellence compared to other similiar games. Unlike Dungeon Defender, you must have close cooperation with your partner in OMD2. Or you will surely be defeated by the orc very soon. Heroism creed is not necessary and is a poisonous seed to the playing experience. I remember when playing co-op in Dungeon Defenders, the only thing I can do was to rest and watch beside if one of my partners used the magician class. That was so boring that I gave up playing with others. If you worry about how to combine various stuffs, this game has the weekly challange to teach you the trick of most stuffs. If you are a fan of tower defense game and co-op, this game would be the one you must have.

content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
												I found Orcs Must Die! 2 to be a very fun experience. It is a 3rd person tower defense-style game, where the objective is to stop orcs from getting to a rift by utilizing various traps and weapons/spells. If you enjoyed the first game, you will definately enjoy this one as well- same orc slaughter, but more traps and weapons to use and upgrade. Orcs Must Die! 2 has a big upgrade system- you get "skulls" after each map to spend on upgrading your traps and weapons in many different ways. The better you do, the more skulls you get, and your upgrades persist thoughout all of the modes, allowing you to tackle the very hard modes such as endless and nightmare. There is also is coop, which I think is a big selling point for this game. I just completed the story mode with my friend, and it was a ton of fun. Watching your combined traps massacre hundreds of orcs as they try to pass by is just so satisfying. As you get into harder levels, teamwork becomes very important as you try to hold the line against and army of orcs.Even after you complete the story, there is still much you can do- endless mode (never ending waves of orcs, see how long you can last), nightmare mode (harder difficulty, but you keep your previous upgrades as I mentioned before), and many other modes.There are a couple of downsides, though, that I will mention. First off, the in-game voice chat is downright awful, and overrides the steam chat so you can't use it. There is no way to turn it off, so my friend and I just made it push-to-talk, bound the key to something we never used, and then used skype or mumble.Also, there really isn't much of a "story", it is not what this game's focus is- it is all about the gameplay. So if you are a person who is looking for a good story to drive you through the game, this is not it.This game is not for everyone. If you don't like 3rd person action or tower/wave defense games, I don't think this will really change your mind about the genres. But if you have any interest at all in the game, I would definitely pick it up. It is very good at what it does.Lastly, many of the levels seem to be made with coop in mind. If you plan to play though this game solo, you might have a difficult time getting through some of the levels.Overall, this game was a blast to play with my friend. If you are looking for a good coop game to play with a buddy, I strongly recommend you try out Orcs Must Die! 2. Even alone, though, this game can still be a fun time. It has a light sense of humor about it that makes it all the more enjoyable, despite the fact that you are slaughtering orcs by the thousands!

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 17, 2013
												This game is very...unexpectedly engrossing. The developer team made many efforts for the combination of stuffs. At first, it has the most amount of stuffs(including weapons, trinkets and guardians) so far during the tower defense genre. Secondly, the combination of different traps, weapons and trinkets makes its strategies much more extensive and variable. All right, I admit its normal mode is quite a bit easy. But in nightmare and endless mode,you will pay more concentration on the combination of different useful stuffs for victory. Its co-op mode is another excellence compared to other similiar games. Unlike Dungeon Defender, you must have close cooperation with your partner in OMD2. Or you will surely be defeated by the orc very soon. Heroism creed is not necessary and is a poisonous seed to the playing experience. I remember when playing co-op in Dungeon Defenders, the only thing I can do was to rest and watch beside if one of my partners used the magician class. That was so boring that I gave up playing with others. If you worry about how to combine various stuffs, this game has the weekly challange to teach you the trick of most stuffs. If you are a fan of tower defense game and co-op, this game would be the one you must have.

content:
Posted: January 14
												Overall Score 9/10Fun factor 8/10Control and Gameplay 9/10Graphics 8/10Sound 9/10Replayability 9/10As a sequel to the original Orcs Must Die goes it's almost perfect as they addressed a lot of the issue that plagued the first game. The developers added multiplayer and skins adding hours of replayability with friends. They also fixing the taxing issue of playing Nightmare Mode allowing a build phase before the level starts. Multiplayer can be a bit buggy at times and if you crash or dc you lose all the progress made on the map of choice. It can be frustrating at times but enjoying the steampunk-isk tower defender with friends adds so much more debt to the game. Like with the original if you can pick it up for 50%-90% off it’s well worth the time and money.

												FUN Trap Defense!  Gibs & flyin' ragdolls galore.  The comedy actually makes me laugh, as it's quite dark, yet with that TF2 sort of physics feel that makes for 3 Stooges escapades when traps are launched..  There is always another reason to play a level another way for strategy, score, or just plain silliness.  Although a few of the levels feel a bit cramped or limited, by changing traps or weaponry one can overcome and appreciate the puzzler aspect of the game, hidden beaneath all the gore & violence.  "Orcs Must Die 2" is a really good time.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2015
												I love it.I'm a HUGE fan of the "Deception" games and "Tecmo's Deception" (the first one on PS1) is still one of my favorite games of all time. This game is great too, but in this game you can, and in most cases have to, also directly attack your enemies. The traps are all well thought out and interact with eachother very nicely, though not for the orcs.Level designs are fantastic allowing different tactics to beat them. You'll run around them thinking of where you want to throw which traps. Then the horde starts flowing and you need to improvise.Both characters have some unique traps and weapons that only they can use.If you have the first game, this game has redone levels from it outside the main story.There's a good amount of enemy variety, each with their own strengths / weaknesses. There's a wide selection of weapons and trinkets which can give you magic attacks, or abilities, or buffs etc..There's many types of traps, but you can only take a handfull with you. Less if you want to take an extra weapon or trinket so you'll have to plan your strategy carefully before you even begin. Each trap is further varied by how you upgrade them, and you can respec the traps/weapons/trinkets you have and how they are upgraded any time in the menu.I recomend the "franchise pack" that comes with the both games and all the DLC.

content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												Opening caveat:  I am not traditionally a person that plays Tower Defense games.  This is in fact my first one.  To get right to the point of it...I loved the game.  If the name wasn't a dead giveaway, the game has a silly, lighthearted tone to most of it that, when combined with the creative ways you can inflict mass orc genocide (some favorites being hurling them by the packs into bottomless chasms with a well timed gust of wind and launching them ragdoll-style for their afternoon lava bath), leads to plenty of destructive catharsis.  While you can play all the missions single player...the game is at its best (IMO) when played with a friend.  Many a map benefits heavily from having a second mind on hand to help combat the games challenges, and with co-op your individual action bar is halved so it emphasizes working and planning together.  The missions also reward player skill with the main currency of the game, skulls.  Doing things like beating a mission within a certain time limit...not letting anyone through your defenses...and even "hidden" bonuses like not using mana or not taking damage all reward you with additional skulls after the level.  If however you're not that great at pulling things off that way, levels can be farmed repeatedly for unlimited skulls so you aren't punished harshly.In conclusion...recommended.  Get a friend...get some chips...and get killing.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												I was a bit hesitant buying this at first, seeing as I don't have any friends to play this with, and it's designed as co-op. I wish I bought it earlier. It is well possible to beat the game single player, though at times it can feel a little overwhelming. I've beaten the campaign, but have not beaten the DLC's yet, as I have yet to try them. If the only thing preventing you from buying this is the fact that it's designed for co-op, just get it. If you get stuck, watch a guide. Fryedegg's channel on Youtube was a great help to me on some of the harder levels. I have yet to try the levels on Nightmare mode (Hardmode) seeing as I'm farming skulls to make things easier. If you're thrown off by me saying you need to spend time farming, you don't. I just am to make things easier.You can reset the upgrades, refunding 100% of what was spent, which is a feature I wish i'd figured out before I was halfway through the game.This game is extremely fun, moddable, has a lot of replayable value, beatable in single-player, has a co-op mode, is better when eating tacos (What game isn't?) and... well... yeah. Get it.

												If your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

content:
Posted: November 23, 2012
												Orcs Must Die 2 is really more of the same, but this time it's bigger and, in some ways, even better. There are quite a lot of new traps, it introduces online co-op, collecting skulls has a better purpose and there's more replayability in general, thanks to Endless Mode.Graphically it looks the same and the one liners are once again amusing. The sounds in general (traps, kills, orcs, you name it) don't disappoint.As you can see it's a complete package and, considering the price, it's truly worth your money.[Rating: 88/100]

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2012
												If you have any interest in tower defence you should already own this.Combining 3rd person shooter and Tower defence, Orcs Must Die 2 allows constantly exciting gameplay with tactical thought like no other. The hordes of enemies overrun the screen with countless numbers as they run through carefully constructed death trap mazes and meet grizzly doom while you blast them away.Tons of traps, weapons and everything else each with a unique upgrade tree which when attempting to max out every item can take days. (I’m not even close with 33 hours)Comparable only to Dungeon Defenders, Orcs Must Die 2 is quite simply a masterpiece.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2014
												Initially this game was fun.  The wave based defense was challenging and the mechanics were fresh.  The problem is once you continue to play past an hour or two.  The game turns into an endless grind without anything new.  While some may enjoy that type of game play, when it comes to wave defense, it gets a bit dull and mindless.  If you're looking for a wave defense game to burn time and you like that sort of micromanagement, this game is definitely a good buy for the price.  I, unfortunately, would not recommend the game.

content:
Posted: March 4, 2013
												Fast-paced and action-packed games with simple, challenging gameplay and a humorous story, as well as several other modes to play in? This game has it all. Take the role of either the robust war mage or the crafty sorceress and fight off hordes of orcs with your large variety of upgradeable, disposable traps and your own upgradeable weapons and accessories. Play with a friend, or slaughter them all yourself. I personally love games that are simple and fast-paced, but also challenging, just like this one, and I'm finding it extremely addicting!

content:
Posted: August 6, 2014
												This game is fun and interesting. Imagine a regular tower defense, but instead of doing everything in God View, you're actually running around on the map setting up traps, towers and minions to help you kill waves of orcs.The fact that you're able to help out by attacking with a vast variation of weapons and trinkets completes this game. You even get to upgrade defences you think are useful with ingame currency.Don't be fooled by my play time, I used to play this on a different account and put quite a few hours into Endless mode with friends. While it doesnt have insane amounts of replayability, it is definitely worth trying out if you've never played this genre of games before.

content:
Posted: May 20, 2015
												Dungeon Defenders was the first tower defense game I played and I couldn't get into it. It wasn't a bad game by any means, but the animation felt too slow paced for my liking and I couldn't get into the leveling and gear upgrades as much as I usually would in an RPG.A friend got me Orcs Must Die 2 to play with him and although I was skeptical at first, I enjoyed (and am still enjoying) the absolute hell out of it. It's much faster pace and spending talent points (or skulls) for weapon / trap upgrades has never been more fun. This is surprising to me because I usually prefer RPG elements in video games, and this one doesn't have any really, but I enjoyed it regardless. If you're looking for a great tower defense, you probably want to check this one out.

content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
												The sequel to Orcs Must Die! is by itself a slightly worse game than the original, however it brings with it the addition of a co-op mode which can easily greatly improve your enjoyment of the game.The game suffers from the same issues as the original, mediocre level design and unbalanced traps/weapons. However it does bring with it some improvements as well. For instance in this game you only get some traps and weapons by default as you progress through the campaign, the others you have to buy with skulls, which you get by doing well in a level and picking up if they drop from an enemy. This adds another level to the game, and with the option to refund your skulls for free any time you want to, you can try out different styles of gameplay every single time.However I was not feeling the atmosphere of the game as I did in the original, that with the addition of new monster types, which seem to be there just to add to the number of different monsters, makes this game slightly worse than the original in my opinion. That is if you're only playing it in single player, however since the game is built more around the co-op aspect if you play it with someone else it becomes better than the original.7½ / 10
